Award.AwardTitle: GOALI - Collaborative Research: The Impact of Chemically Induced Stresses on Kinetic Processes and Degradation Mechanisms in Non-Stoichiometric Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This research project focuses on several oxide materials that are important in energy related applications. The central phenomena of interest are linked to internal stresses that are created by changes in composition (for example, adding and removing lithium in a battery material). The specific findings from this project are contributing directly to the development of improved electrodes for high energy density lithium ion batteries for hybrid and electric vehicles, and improved materials for applications in fuel cells and catalysis. Knowledge transfer is occurring through both public dissemination and direct interactions with researchers and General Motors.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: In ionic materials there is a complex interplay between internal stresses, defects in the material, electrochemical phenomena and kinetic processes (e.g., diffusion and phase transformations). These stresses lead to degradation and performance limitations in new materials that are being explored for both solid oxide fuel cells and lithium ion batteries. Scientific understanding of these stress-related issues is currently very limited. In this project, research into these phenomena is based on systematic and strategically planned investigations that closely integrate theory and experiments. The efforts at Brown University employ precise in situ measurements of stresses along with other experimental methods to develop novel approaches for probing a variety of complex phenomena where stress interactions with fundamental mechanisms are poorly understood (e.g., defect association, grain boundary segregation, multicomponent diffusion, etc.). Interpretation of these data relies on atomic scale modeling at Michigan State University. Students and faculty from both Universities are working directly with Dr. Yan Wu and other researchers at General Motors, in ways that expand educational outcomes and enhance knowledge transfer to industry. The overall understanding of stress effects on kinetic processes and degradation mechanisms obtained from this project is also relevant to a broader range of ionic solids.

Institution.Name: Brown University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BROWN UNIVERSITY IN PROVIDENCE IN THE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND AND PROVIDENCE PLANTATIONS

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project involves Brown University, Michigan State University, and General Motors.  The research focuses on several different oxide materials that are important in energy related applications.  The central phenomena of interest are linked to internal stresses that are created by changes in composition (for example, adding and removing lithium in a battery material).  In the oxide materials that were investigated, there is a complex interplay between internal stresses, defects in the material, electrochemical phenomena and kinetic processes (e.g., diffusion and phase transformations). Research into these phenomena was based on systematic and strategically planned investigations that closely integrate experiments (at Brown) and simulations (at MSU) to probe a variety of complex phenomena where stress interactions with fundamental mechanisms are poorly understood (e.g., defect association, multicomponent ions, diffusion, phase changes, etc.).  Students and faculty from both Universities also worked directly with Dr. Yan Wu and other researchers at General Motors, in ways that expanded the educational outcomes and enhanced knowledge transfer to industry. 

Much of the research conducted in this project was focused on nickel-manganese-cobalt (NMC) oxides that are widely used as cathodes for lithium ion batteries.  The new knowledge that was obtained provides information about the relationships between oxygen loss, stress, and the formation of surface layers in these materials.  The discovery that silicon doping improves the performance of NMC cathode materials can potentially lead to improved Li ion batteries for a variety of applications.  The predicted impact of oxygen vacancies on Li mobility in these types of materials is also important, because Li diffusion is directly linked to power limitations in Li ion batteries.  Additional work was also conducted with cerium dioxide and lanthanum strontium ferrite, which are promising electrolyte and electrode materials for improved solid oxide fuel cells.  Here, NSF supported work demonstrated that oxygen removal at high temperatures leads directly to much higher stresses occur at the interfaces between crystalline grains in ceria.  Strong defect interactions also lead to oxygen conductivity loss in lanthanum strontium ferrite, causing degradation.  To further advance the fundamental study of chemical strains that are relevant to a broad range of chemical-mechanical coupling phenomena, a general method was developed to accurately predict the anisotropic chemical strains for point defects. The predicted chemical strains agree well with experimental observations in the materials investigated in this program, and also lead to improved understanding of other related phenomena in complex oxides.  This work highlights the need to consider chemical strain tensors in a variety of materials.  In general, the overall understanding of electrochemical-coupled-stress effects on kinetic processes and degradation mechanisms obtained from this project are relevant to a broad range of ionic solids.

The specific findings from this project are directly relevant to the development of improved electrodes for high energy density lithium ion batteries for hybrid and electric vehicles, and to improved materials for applications in fuel cells and catalysis.  The overall understanding of defect interactions in ionic material have already made an impact on battery and solid oxide fuel cell communities, and some of this is being extended to new applications, such as thermochemical hydrogen generation. It is expected that the knowledge gained in this project will be extended to all-solid-state lithium batteries, nuclear materials, and other ionic conducting materials.   

The major outcome/achievements of the project include important method developments and scientific discoveries, which were documented in publications and presented at major conferences. Knowledge transfer occurred through this public dissemination and also by direct interactions with researchers and General Motors that are noted above.  Research funds were primarily used to support PhD students at Brown and Michigan State University (both female).  Undergraduate women from Wellesley College also received support to conduct summer research projects at Brown. The research topics on materials simulation and batteries were also incorporated into outreach activities at MSU (Girls' STEM Day and Introduce a Girl to Engineering Day).

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2019
Modified by: Brian W Sheldon
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This collaborative project involves Brown University, Michigan State University, and General Motors. The research focuses on several different oxide materials that are important in energy related applications. The central phenomena of interest are linked to internal stresses that are created by changes in composition (for example, adding and removing lithium in a battery material). In the oxide materials that were investigated, there is a complex interplay between internal stresses, defects in the material, electrochemical phenomena and kinetic processes (e.g., diffusion and phase transformations). Research into these phenomena was based on systematic and strategically planned investigations that closely integrate experiments (at Brown) and simulations (at MSU) to probe a variety of complex phenomena where stress interactions with fundamental mechanisms are poorly understood (e.g., defect association, multicomponent ions, diffusion, phase changes, etc.). Students and faculty from both Universities also worked directly with Dr. Yan Wu and other researchers at General Motors, in ways that expanded the educational outcomes and enhanced knowledge transfer to industry. Much of the research conducted in this project was focused on nickel-manganese-cobalt (NMC) oxides that are widely used as cathodes for lithium ion batteries. The new knowledge that was obtained provides information about the relationships between oxygen loss, stress, and the formation of surface layers in these materials. The discovery that silicon doping improves the performance of NMC cathode materials can potentially lead to improved Li ion batteries for a variety of applications. The predicted impact of oxygen vacancies on Li mobility in these types of materials is also important, because Li diffusion is directly linked to power limitations in Li ion batteries. Additional work was also conducted with cerium dioxide and lanthanum strontium ferrite, which are promising electrolyte and electrode materials for improved solid oxide fuel cells. Here, NSF supported work demonstrated that oxygen removal at high temperatures leads directly to much higher stresses occur at the interfaces between crystalline grains in ceria. Strong defect interactions also lead to oxygen conductivity loss in lanthanum strontium ferrite, causing degradation. To further advance the fundamental study of chemical strains that are relevant to a broad range of chemical-mechanical coupling phenomena, a general method was developed to accurately predict the anisotropic chemical strains for point defects. The predicted chemical strains agree well with experimental observations in the materials investigated in this program, and also lead to improved understanding of other related phenomena in complex oxides. This work highlights the need to consider chemical strain tensors in a variety of materials. In general, the overall understanding of electrochemical-coupled-stress effects on kinetic processes and degradation mechanisms obtained from this project are relevant to a broad range of ionic solids. The specific findings from this project are directly relevant to the development of improved electrodes for high energy density lithium ion batteries for hybrid and electric vehicles, and to improved materials for applications in fuel cells and catalysis. The overall understanding of defect interactions in ionic material have already made an impact on battery and solid oxide fuel cell communities, and some of this is being extended to new applications, such as thermochemical hydrogen generation. It is expected that the knowledge gained in this project will be extended to all-solid-state lithium batteries, nuclear materials, and other ionic conducting materials. The major outcome/achievements of the project include important method developments and scientific discoveries, which were documented in publications and presented at major conferences. Knowledge transfer occurred through this public dissemination and also by direct interactions with researchers and General Motors that are noted above. Research funds were primarily used to support PhD students at Brown and Michigan State University (both female). Undergraduate women from Wellesley College also received support to conduct summer research projects at Brown. The research topics on materials simulation and batteries were also incorporated into outreach activities at MSU (Girls' STEM Day and Introduce a Girl to Engineering Day).
